all_paragraphs: The customer experience is the next competitive battleground. ~ Jerry Gregoire
Your most unhappy customers are your greatest source of learning. ~ Bill Gates

For any business, customer goodwill is a key driver for success. Running an efficient and effective IT Services Management System goes a long way towards achieving customer goodwill and gaining the competitive edge.
Let us explore how Natural Language Processing (NLP) can be applied to reduce the Mean Time To Repair (MTTR) for service requests or incidents in production environments.
Let us see a hypothetical case study.

“ABC Fashion” had launched their membership rewards program with a rejuvenated version of the online portal for customers. Behind the scenes, the IT infrastructure had 3 new applications that contributed to 15 more integrations between upstream and downstream systems. A 10-member IT Services team, internally divided into 3 sub-teams each handling a specific area of integration, had been delivering top quality services until the new program went live and disrupted a few things:
“Houston — we have problems” ! !

> Volume of service requests went up 5 times — partly due to customer’s lack of understanding of the new system and partly due to known issues in the integration of systems. Team was unable to abide by the Service Level Agreement (SLA) with such high volumes.

> Requests from customers covered a wide range of issues described in free text format which were difficult to categorize manually during analysis phase. Often, customers did not select the right categories and subcategories in the “Contact Us” web-forms that led to incorrect categorization and IT Services team assignments. Reassignments of such requests contribute to the MTTR.
> Volume of production incidents increased due to more integration points in the system. Some of the incidents could however be fixed by simple steps.

> Requests didn’t get the appropriate priority until a team member had analyzed the issue. For example, portal login failures or application downtime should have be addressed with highest priority whatever the default priority was set during the request creation.
Do we have a solution ?
Thankfully, YES. Further brainstorming revealed that these problems could be mitigated if the service requests and incidents are properly categorized and labeled before reaching the IT support teams.

Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a subfield of artificial intelligence concerned with interactions between computers and human (natural) languages. It is used to apply machine learning algorithms to text and speech.

For example, we can use NLP to create systems like speech recognition, document summarization, machine translation, spam detection, named entity recognition, question answering, autocomplete, predictive typing and so on.
For the problem in discussion, NLP can be used to make the classification “Content Based” where a trained model is used to predict a category by analyzing the content of the request.

NLP is an ocean with tons and tons of text processing approaches and algorithms available to us, and it is continuously improving with each passing day as we try to get closer to the human expertise in understanding text.
However, simplicity pays off often when the problem at hand deserves so.
Let’s explore a very simple approach to solve the classification problem of ABC fashion store by following the development model mentioned above.
The following are some hypothetical but real world categories which can be used by ABC Fashion Store. They are non-overlapping and covers most of the type of issues generally reported.

Performance of a model implies how well the model is predicting an outcome based on the features it has learnt. For the present problem, performance would be measured based on how correctly the model is predicting a category for a Service Request out of the 6 categories mentioned below.

There are many ways by which model performance can be measured, of which the F1 score is simple and easy to use. F1 score is based on two metrics — Precision and Recall — which dictate what fraction of the predicted values are correct and what fraction of correct known values are predicted.
For more information, please check : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F1_score
So for this problem, F1 Score is used as a performance metric.

Assuming that a labeled data set of Service Requests is available (may be human labeling done on historical data of last 2 years) that has all the relevant text attributes along with the target label, exploratory data analysis can give important insights into the data like:
> Counts of records grouped by the labeled target — what are the top 5 categories in this data set? Is it heavily skewed on any one type?

> How good are the text attributes for analysis? Are there too long / too short words? Is there any PII data which need to be removed? Are their multiple versions of the same text — “sign in”, “signin”, “sign on”, “log on” have same meaning and can be converted to “login”.

Pandas is an excellent package for Exploratory Data Analysis. After importing source data from json or csv formats into a Pandas data frame, various functions can be applied to understand the characteristics of the data and to extract relevant data based on regular expressions.

For the current problem, a subset of fields from the Service Request like “Request Short Description”, “Detailed Description”, “Additional Notes”, “Work Log” etc and concatenate them to get source data. The entire text in the source may not be useful, we unwanted common lines are removed to make a cleaner text.

A text classifier model is supposed to predict the category of any input text data based on the “features” that it had learnt from a similar labeled data set from same data domain. If we have some historical Service Request data which had been classified into one of the aforementioned categories during the analysis of the issue, that “knowledge” needs to be Raw text need to be therefore converted into feature values which a model will be able to understand. To put in on a high level, a text sentence is converted into a vector of numbers — real or integer — based on some rules and a predetermined “vocabulary”.
Complex pre-trained encoders were not required here as the focus was on existence of keywords and not on specific context and order of words in the text.

Scikitlearn is one of the most easy-to-use packages that can be used for Text Encoding and model development. It has a good variety of text analysis libraries along with utilities and optimization algorithms to get us started on NLP.

The following approach is followed for model development and testing. Model development is an iterative process where the model is evaluated based on the model metric — F1 Score — and if the results seem to be unsatisfactory, the model parameters may be tuned and the training process is started again. For classification problems, a “confusion matrix” is particularly helpful to examine specific cases where the model is performing poorly, meaning it is predicting a different label for the input data. Such cases need to be revisited, especially with respect to availability of data a

If subsequent training and testing does not improve the F1 score much, then data set size or number of features in text encoding may be revisited. If there is still nothing left to improve, it may be assumed that the model is optimized.

Once the model is built and tested, the most important part is deployment. While most of the modern ITSM tools now have out-of-the-box AI features that can be customized, having an in-house built classifier model always helps in having more control and versatility.
Below are a few ways a classifier model can be deployed:

The best way, however, to deploy the model to production, is to expose its prediction function as an API which enables real-time integration with the ITSM tool thereby enabling on-the-fly classification of the Service Request at the moment of its creation.

Container based solutions encapsulate all the model data, metadata, libraries and utility functions within a container “image” and bundles the model as a portable application. These images can be deployed to AWS or Azure cloud container registries that make it even more manageable with respect to infrastructure, scalability, security and availability.
Finally, it is an architectural decision in the best interests of the organization based on its available technical stack, budget and capabilities.
For those who are aware of the NLP concepts, toolkits and jargon, below is a very basic and partially tuned sample model development approach:
> Input data set : Service Request data dump csv file from ITSM tool with labeling done.
Independent variable X = augmented, processed and standardized text from fields of interest like Short Description, Description, Closing Comments, Additional Comments.
Dependent variable Y = one of the 6 target labels
A maximum of 3000 words are chosen(max_features) for the vocabulary and only words occurring in more than 5 examples are selected. Single words are chosen for pattern matching (ngram_range=(1, 1))

Note: There are a lot of other encoding techniques available and may be applied depending on the type of problem — for example : tfidf vectorizer, word embeddings using pre-trained models like GloVe, Word2Vec etc. But such complex encoding is not considered for this particular classification problem for the sake of simplicity. Also, a classification problem, like this one, may just be good enough with examination of occurrences of words instead of their relative order and position/context; having a CountVectorizer is a good and simple start instead of complex word embeddings using GRU/LSTM/BERT etc.
Indepenent (input X) data is encoded into feature vectors by the count vectorizer.
Dependent (target Y) data is encoded into a one-hot vector for number of categories = 6.
Assuming we had 6000 examples in our data set and we have split it 80–20 into Dev-CrossValidation sets, the encoding would look something like this:

It can be observed how the input variables x_train, x_test are converted from single dimensional vectors of strings into encoded sparse matrices X_train_vec,X_test_vec and output target categories are encoded into vectors from , y_train, y_test to one-hot representations y_train_oh, y_test_oh.
> Model type: Shallow Artificial Neural Network
> Model architecture and Hyperparameters (partially tuned):
SoftMax classifier (6 units — one per category).
Optimizer = Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD)
Number of iterations (epochs) = 40
Keras with Tensorflow backend is used to build the model in Python.

We see how we can plot loss and accuracy values against the number of iterations of the model. Accuracy reaches more than 96% with the training set — but it doesn’t mean the model is accurate. It has to be cross verified and tested with unseen data to see if there is over-fitting.
Running the prediction on test data set may lead to false positives and false negatives. A sample classification report and confusion matrix is as follows:

Very low F1 scores are seen for category 4. A lot of overlaps are seen between categories 0 and 1 (2nd row and 1st column of the confusion matrix) — meaning if the actual category (Ground Truth) of a service request was 1, it was wrongly labeled as 0 by the model.
> Saving the encoder and model and metadata for future predictions:
For future predictions, both the model and the encoder may to be saved for future access to the predictor process.
These can be loaded back to the memory when the model prediction API is initialized:
ABC Fashion was finally able to achieve the golden reward of high customer satisfaction by implementing a Classifier for their ITSM tool. The new classifier helped in the following ways:
> MTTR reduced by a significant amount.

> 50% of the Service Requests that had earlier required the same set of resolution steps were now automatically resolved as soon as they were created. This was possible because the issues were labeled accordingly and forwarded to the automated bot for the resolution steps.
> ITSM reports and dashboards could report issues by category in real time giving great insights on the frequency and trends of Service Request types.
> Critical system alerts got tagged as Severity 1 issues and flagged for immediate response.
> Workloads of the team got normalized giving them chance to work on further enhancements.

The classifier model we saw here, like any software developed and deployed, need monitoring and maintenance. New input patterns, skewness of predictions, dipping F1 scores, introduction of new categories, enhancements to the deployed application for performance and scaling, tuning models for better predictions — all these fall into a lifecycle.

Modern ITSM tools have out-of the-box AI based text processing plugins which are purely managed by the tool provider. Such tools make development easy and hassle-free, sometimes called “Zero-Code”. However, building an in-house model provides better control and more scope of improvisations as compared to managed solutions.
